Diwali.Description: Diwali, the Festival of Lights, signifies the victory of light over darkness and good over evil. It involves lighting lamps, exchanging gifts, and enjoying festive meals.
Diwali.Significance: Celebrates the return of Lord Rama to Ayodhya and the vanquishing of the demon king Ravana.

Holi.Description: Holi, the Festival of Colors, is celebrated with colorful powders, water balloons, and playful festivities. It symbolizes the triumph of good over evil and the arrival of spring.
Holi.Significance: Celebrates the love between Lord Krishna and Radha and the victory of good (Krishna) over evil (Holika).

Eid-al-Fitr.Description: Eid-al-Fitr marks the end of Ramadan, a month of fasting and prayer for Muslims. It's a time for prayers, feasting, and giving to charity.
Eid-al-Fitr.Date: Varies (based on the Islamic lunar calendar)
Eid-al-Fitr.Significance: Celebrates the end of Ramadan and the beginning of Shawwal.

Navratri.Description: Navratri is a nine-night festival dedicated to the goddess Durga. It involves fasting, dancing (Garba and Dandiya), and worshiping the goddess.
Navratri.Significance: Celebrates the victory of goddess Durga over the demon Mahishasura.

Christmas.Description: Christmas is celebrated by Christians in India to honor the birth of Jesus Christ. It includes church services, carol singing, decorating Christmas trees, and gift-giving.
Christmas.Significance: Celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.

Raksha Bandhan.Description: Raksha Bandhan is a festival celebrating the bond between brothers and sisters. Sisters tie a protective thread (rakhi) on their brothers' wrists, and brothers give gifts in return.
Raksha Bandhan.Significance: Symbolizes the love and protection between siblings.

Ganesh Chaturthi.Description: Ganesh Chaturthi is dedicated to Lord Ganesha, the elephant-headed god of wisdom and prosperity. It involves the installation of Ganesha idols and immersion in water.
Ganesh Chaturthi.Significance: Celebrates the birth of Lord Ganesha and seeks his blessings.

Durga Puja.Description: Durga Puja is a grand celebration in West Bengal, honoring goddess Durga. It includes elaborate decorations, idol processions, and cultural performances.
Durga Puja.Significance: Celebrates the goddess's victory over the buffalo demon Mahishasura.

Pongal.Description: Pongal is a harvest festival celebrated in South India. It involves cooking a special dish called 'Pongal' and offering it to the sun god.
Pongal.Significance: Marks the harvest season and expresses gratitude to nature.

Lohri.Description: Lohri is a Punjabi winter festival celebrated with bonfires, music, and dance. It marks the end of winter and the arrival of longer days.
Lohri.Significance: Celebrates the winter solstice and harvest season.
